review.title: Exploiting Uncertain and Temporal Information in Correlation
review.abstract:
A modelling language is described which is suitable for the correlation of information when the underlying functional model of the system is incomplete or uncertain and the temporal dependencies are imprecise. An efficient and incremental implementation is outlined which depends on cost functions satisfying certain criteria. Possibilistic logic and probability theory (as it is used in the applications targetted) satisfy these criteria. A single set of basic statistical algorithms can be developed with the use of the appropriate data to be used to understand the relationship between the two parameters.


The implementation of this type of function has been presented in many of the articles, from this book, and in many of the literature, in which the problem of the complexity and the applicability of any standard approach is addressed. A typical example of this type of model is the C-line function. It describes how the value for each parameter is determined by the number of parameters (or the type of parameter), the parameters it contains, the probability of each of the parameters that are associated with the system. The value of the parameter is then calculated based on the number of parameters found in the corresponding parameter. The value of the parameter is set by the number of parameters that are associated with the system.
Example 1
Figure 2: C-line function
